product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: It's still the truth even if it didn't happen
review_body:
I first read Kesey's Cuckoo's Nest back in high school, roughly around the same time our psych teacher screened the Jack Nicholson film for us, and loved it. It's not hard to see why: the novel is beautifully written, with one of the most interesting unreliable narrators in all of fiction, and has enough FIGHT THE POWER to satiate any teenager.

What's odd is what I remembered about it in the years between readings. The ending stuck, obviously, along with the gist of the plot - non-crazy man pretends to be crazy to get out of jail and winds up discovering just how insane the world can be - but if you'd said One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest to me, the image that my mind would immediately have conjured would be the surreal night terrors of Chief Broom, trapped in bed as the bottom drops out of his world revealing the true machinery of life, where men are strung up on meat hooks before being sliced into rust and ash.

So I remembered the metaphor and the prose, and happily forgot the underlying racism and misogyny. I've no problem at all with the antagonist being a vile, controlling woman, but it's hard to sympathize with a hero whose suggestion for improving her temperament is sexual assault. I take the work as a product of its age...but still. Gah.

Kesey's novel is still vibrant and riveting, and though the passing decades and (thankfully) changing times make its imperfections seem more glaring, its underlying message about living in a world that chews up and spits out anyone who doesn't conform to the rules and standards of normalcy remains as pertinent as ever. So it's still the truth...even if it didn't happen.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: Got to Keep the Loonies on the Path...
review_body: Best known today for the movie version with Jack Nicholson, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is basically the story of a power struggle between the free-spirited and fairly amoral McMurphy (whose rap sheet includes statutory rape that he treats as a big joke) and the iron-fisted and repressed head nurse Ratchet. When that theme is at the forefront this is a wonderful story and it produces a number of excellent set pieces of passive aggressive confrontation between the two as they manipulate the others to be on their side in their dispute.    The story is narrated in first person by \\"Chief\\" Bromden, a half-Indian inmate of the mental asylum where the story takes place, and that may not have been the best choice. The problem is that Bromden's narration is constantly sidetracked by his own hallucinations and remembrances of his past (which may or may not be accurate). To me these passages bog down the narrative and sidetrack the main story.    There is also a nasty strain of misogyny underlying the narrative, as Ratchet's bullying nature is entwined with her gender (there seems to be a particular fascination with the size of her breasts) while two whores the inmates become involved with are treated sympathetically because, well, they are what the male characters want them to be--easy. The final confrontation between McMurphy and Ratchet isn't cathartic so much as sleazy and cringe-inducing even if you are on McMurphy's side. Twenty-first century readers may also be put off by the way the black characters are treated and referred to but this isn't unusual for a book published by a white author around 1960.    In this his debut novel, Ken Kesey displays an excellent writing flair and a sense of the dramatic but I think he strained too hard for profundity with Bromden's extended speculations on his life.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
I watched the movie a few months ago. I enjoyed it greatly. I read that Kesey hated the movie and refused to watch it, though, and I was curious. So, I purchased the book and read it. The book blows the movie out of the water. Much more depth to the characters not found on screen (it seems the movie was mostly a showcase for Nicholson). We are told the story from the perspective of Chief Bromden, and his paranoid rantings make the book greatly enjoyable to read. Instead of just watching McMurphy on screen, we see his impact on a very personal level with the emotionally confused Bromden. It's a great book, it made me laugh on several occasions along with generally feeling sympathy for the characters. Now that I've read the novel, I can understand Kesey's dissatisfaction with the film. They sucked the life out of his characters: it became a battle of McMurphy and the nurse. The movie is still enjoyable, but the book offers so much more.

If you enjoyed the film, give the book a read.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: One Flew West! One Flew East! One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest!
review_body: Ken Kesey was inspired to write this classic American novel based on his own experiences working in a mental hospital in the 1960s. Life isn't easy there for the patients led by the infamous Nurse Ratched. An American Native Indian, Chief Bromden, narrates this dark and uplifting tale of life there.    Until recently, many mental asylums have closed permanently and left abandoned. This mental hospital lacks the warmth and encouragement for the patients to get better.    Nurse Ratched is determined to keep a strict control over her Ward. She fixes the time. She puts the Ward in a foglike state to keep them obedient and to her will. She also makes most of the decisions and has help from three sadistic African American men to keep the patients all in line. Nurse Ratched is revelation of a female character. Nurses were seen as maternal and nurturing but not Nurse Ratched. She is an unlikable character with a sadistic element in her nature. She is not the kind of nurse that you want for a mental ward.    The patients include the introduction of a colorful Randle P. MacMurphy who chooses to spend time there than a prison. He would have been safer there. Nurse Ratched wasn't going to let him take over her Ward. She was determined to make an example of him.    The novel is about 300 pages long. It is both an entertaining and enlightening read. This book probably changed the way that mental hospitals were viewed as a place for the undesirables and outcasts. There the patients were subjected to abuse of all kinds and inhumane treatment.    Like Upton Sinclair's classic novel, \\"The Jungle,\\" this novel explored and changed society's view of mental health. I would have wondered if Kesey had more to say about it. This book inspired the classic film of the same name later awarded with Academy Awards. Louise Fletcher was absolutely perfect as Nurse Ratched. Jack Nicholson's performance of R.P. MacMurphy was also wonderful. The other cast members were excellent in their roles. Thisnovel inspired a stage production at theatres as well. The film and stage adaptations were different from the novel. The movie has become a film classic and should never be remade.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: This was also made into a movie, which was excellent. The main character, a criminal everyone calls "Mac" (short for McMurphy), is checked into an insane asylum to avoid prison. He begins making trouble with the inmates, trying to bend the head nurse's rules and encouraging the other inmates to be rebels. The story is all told from the point of view of a very large Native American that Mac calls "Chief," and though he can speak he pretends to be deaf and dumb, just pushing a broom and eavesdropping all the time. Through several very traumatic incidents, "Chief" becomes inspired and unexpectedly embarks on the road to recovery.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
I was assigned this is my literature class last month and just now finished it. This novel was very odd, but I can see why my teacher would have wanted me to read it. The book had some wonderful themes that make you just sit there and think, plus there so much symbolism going on in this book that a discussion on it could go on for hours.

(Spoilers)

This novels Protagonist and Main character are two different people. The protagonist is McMurphy and who the story is mainly about, but Chief is the one that we start and end with. McMurphy is the new guy on the mental ward, and he brings things to the oppressed that they forgot about, laughter, flirting, and singing whenever you please. He shows some of the guys that they aren't actually sick just oppressed, and when everything is said and done. Someone is a martyr and people are healed.

At times there were things in this novel hat were hard to understand, like when Chief has his visions and hallucinations. Kesey doesn't make it obvious or gives any indication about whether they are real or not. So that made this book a slight turn off.

I loved watching the healing process happen, so basically I loved the whole plot line of the book.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
One Flew Over the Cuckooâ€™s Nest is narrated by the point of view of Chief Bromden, a paranoid schizophrenic patient who pretends to be deaf and mute. Through the eyes of Chief Bromden, readers follow the arrival of a convicted criminal, Randle McMurphy, and witness his rebellion against the tyrannical Nurse Ratched and the institution.The book not only concerns with the issue of sanity and insanity, but also the definition of power and freedom, and the insurrection against conformity.

One Flew Over the Cuckooâ€™s Nest asks the questions that are still left unanswered, more than fifty years after the book was published: are we numbed by societal norms? Is it possible to flee from the restraints that society induces upon us? Is it worthwhile to sacrifice oneâ€™s life for a belief as vague as freedom? Are we still waiting for a savior? Ken Kesey presented his answer: Randell Patrick McMurphy and his roaring laugh and cry.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: In a time where those who opposed mainstream opinion were chastised from society, it is easy to understand how Kesey was severely criticized when he first published The One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest. Kesey highlights a different perspective, deeming society and government the oppressors and stressing individuality. The struggle begins when a new patient at a Psychiatric Ward named Randle McMurphy wages war against Nurse Ratched, who is a tyrannical force within the ward. Nurse Ratched is part of a mass machine called the \\"combine\\" which symbolizes the destructive way in which society attempts to control its members. I have to admit, the novel was a slow start, but as it developed I eagerly anticipated the next hilarious plan McMurphy would devise to strip the Nurse of her power (in the end, this coincidentally takes on a literal meaning). I was fascinated by the uncertainty of each patient's sanity, and Kesey provided a perspective that allowed each reader to develop his or her own opinion. A mental patient named Bromden, who experiences frequent hallucinations, narrates the novel. His vivid hallucinations, although considered an example of his mental disability, are actually metaphorical interpretations of how the combine works on its patients. What makes this novel so captivating and unique is that it is told from the perspective of someone who could possibly be mentally disturbed or be completely sane, a man who faked being deaf and dumb for a majority of his time at a mental hospital. Kesey shows that the term \\"normal\\" is subjective; it is forced upon us by society and makes us form preconceived notions of normality. The main characters of the novel attempt to break free from the constraints that have rendered them \\"freaks\\" of society in order learn what it is like to feel normal. I highly recommend this book, and I look forward to reading it again in the near future.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
I decided to read this book because One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest is one of my favorite movies. I ended up finding the book to be far superior to the movie because of the unique perspective achieved by having Chief Bromden narrate the story. Chief Bromden frequently hallucinates that there is a dense fog holding him down and hiding him from others. However, the reader is not ever informed that this fog is imaginary and the only way to pick up on this is to notice how Bromden seems to be the only one bothered by the fog. The fact that Bromden doesn't think anyone else can see him when in this hallucinating state allows him to narrate with an outside perspective . This is not the only advantage of having the mentally insane in a novel.
This book is also unique because Ken Kesey is not restricted to a logical train of thought because a person who is completely insane doesn't have to make any sense. The benefits of this are endless. I particularly enjoy the use of crazy people as comic relief. Colonel Matterson is always yelling such hilarious nonsense as, \\"The but-ter ... is the Re-pub-li-can party. ...\\" and \\"The pillow is ... a horse!\\". Kesey also uses the mentally insane characters to increase the gravity of a situation. An example of this can be found when Old Pete hits one of the aides in the face in a flurry of anger, yelling, \\"I'm tired!\\".
Overall, my favorite aspect of the novel was the storyline itself. I got sucked into the anti-authoritarian messages of the novel and even found myself seething when Nurse Ratched would commit injustices. The ending was a release of all the pent up hatred for Nurse Ratched. When McMurphy finally stopped restraining himself and strangled Nurse Ratched, I found it extremely emotionally gratifying because of how involved I felt I had become in the battle against Nurse Ratched's tyranny. Although tragic, I thought the conclusion with Chief Bromden freeing McMurphy from his \\"already dead\\" state was excellent. This wasthe most entertaining piece of literature I have ever read.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Reading One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest by Ken Kesey will give the reader not only a look into the state of psychiatric care in the mid 20th century, but also will offer a taste of rebellion, self-discovery, and a narrative of the disturbed in a unique context that continues to be enlightening in its wit and its twists. The novel is told from the viewpoint of a half Indian Chief Bromden who describes the hospital's proceedings from his observations on the patients, staff, and their interactions. His attempt to be invisible by pretending to be deaf and dumb allows the reader to indulge in an eavesdropper's perspective constantly. Bromden's hallucinations and fear of an outside controlling force he labels the Combine, establishes the reader in the intriguing mindset of the disturbed. The novel's center conflict is between a  Randle Patrick McMurphy, who feigned insanity to avoid going to prison for battery and gambling, and the head nurse, Mildred Ratched. Ratched runs the hospital with an iron fist, and is described by Bromden to be a t the center of an invisible network of wires in which he controls every facet of the institution. The novel follows McMurphy's continuous attempts to break apart that system, as well as his indirect goal of helping the patients to realize they are men, and not the pawns of an oppressive system. The vibrant and frequent conflicts between the patients led by McMurphy and the staff carry the plot and all add to a continuous build up of tensions between two forces. As the patients become more and more self-discovered the hospital only grows more dangerous and surreal. Kesey uses his personal experience as an orderly at a psychiatric hospital to paint an accurate picture of this world of the disturbed. You will have to experience it yourself to decided whether the staff or the patients are more so.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Ken Kesey's masterpiece gets better every year. I've read the book a dozen times, and It's always been a page turner. Randle Patrick McMurphy, is the last of his kind. He could be a lumber jack, a cowboy, or deep sea fisherman, or anything that requires two hands and a sense of confidence. His reckless bravado, drinking, gambling, and chasing women, are a breath of fresh air in our politically correct and medicated modern world. Through McMurphy's swaggering, Kessy weaves this tragic tale with humor and a sense of hope that a man, even Billity Bibbit, might overcome his fears and stand up to the big nurses of the world even if it is only ends in one last stuttering moment.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: Book is great. Movie...no so much.
review_body: If you watched the movie and thought it sucked, read the book and you'll realize how much the movie really sucked. The movie is worth watching and respectable in its own right, but not anywhere close to being an accurate portrayal of the book. The book is a good read.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: I may have interpreted this differently...
review_body:
I read this book before watching the movie and although Nurse Ratched's infamy goes far beyond the book, I didn't see the story as so black and white.

Having worked with mentally incompetent people, and also having also having had a brief stint in a mental hospital many years ago (and also...having gone to school, which wasn't all that different) I saw this book as a conflict between two extremes in how to deal with the mentally deficient.

Most nurses and caregivers want to avoid getting their patients agitated, which would make their job harder as well. Nurse Ratched is not so different from most people in this way. She is also vindictive and authoritarian, like many incompetent authority figures. Her maliciousness in therapy and her delusions of altruism take her outside the realm of just incompetence, but other than that I saw her as human.

MacMurphy enters the scene and stirs things up. He pals around with the patients and treats them like equals that don't have actual problems. He does some good things, like getting Chief to open up just by talking to him, because he doesn't know \\"the way things have always been\\" or doesn't care, but he also behaves recklessly in other situations. I don't know whether I'd say he treats them like human beings, because he also may be an antisocial personality.

One one extreme, Nurse Ratched treats patients like objects to be minimized and quieted. On the other, McMurphy treats them like his wild-and-crazy drinking buddies.

I especially liked the Chief, who was memorable as a character but also as a plot device as a background person describing the story. Anyone who has experienced \\"select mutism\\" can also identify with reading this person's thoughts even though he never speaks.

I liked the book, although it might be seen in ways that the author didn't intend.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: This book was said to be in good condition.  It had lots of highlighting(several colors), writing in the margins, and very worn.  I wanted this book for my son's college book list and it was embarrassing. I went to Barnes & Noble to purchase the book.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
I've gotta' say that my reading of this novel was undoubtedly colored by the fact that I had just finished Rousseau's Discourse on the Origin and Basis of Inequality Among Men before starting it. I had never seen the movie, so going into it, I was a clean slate. I had no real preconceptions, and thank God for that, because this was one of the most incredibly fresh and interesting novels that I've ever read.

It opens with our narrator, Bromden, \\"Chief\\", giving us a schizophrenic, nightmare rundown of the Asylum, a stronghold of The Combine ruled by the icy Nurse Ratched, \\"Big Nurse.\\" Her almost hypnotic hold over the patients of the ward is challenged by the arrival of Randle Patrick McMurphy - a wild, gambling, Southern, red-headed con-man trying to escape four months on a workfarm by having himself committed. The stage is then set for the clash of two titanic personalities and the forces they come to represent. Faceless, unaccountable, institutional power, The Combine, represented in the figure of Big Nurse. Fundamental humanity, agency, and the dignity of natural man championed by McMurphy.

Because that is what McMurphy becomes to the men on the ward, who are disenfranchised and alienated even within the hospital, which Nurse Ratched strives to make a microcosm of society at large. And man, did I feel the joy of their brief and glorious triumph. Kesey writes with such honesty that, as Bromden says, \\"...it's the truth even if it didn't happen.\\" Bromden's narration is a key part of what makes this novel so stirring. His paranoid schizophrenic fantasies turn the ward into a hellish dystopia, all the more terrifying because he is arguably more attuned to the reality of what is happening than anyone else. His hallucinations are in touch with the unseen, coercive power of the institution, the insidious nature of which is much more dangerous, subversive, and divisive than outright acts of force.

I've seen a lot of criticism of the book online for perceived sexism, which I'm not sure I agree with, as I believe that's not really giving Kesey enough credit. Demasculinization, castration - these are symbols used, but I believe that if you look deeper, Kesey is really talking about the enforced alienation of humanity from our sexuality by society as a means of control and dehumanization. As surely as the sterilized figure of the Big Nurse uses desexualization as a weapon, Candy uses sexuality as a means to heal Billy Bibbit. Indeed, even McMurphy says at the outset that the ball-cutters can be male just as easily as female. The Ward doesn't simply desmaculize the men, Ratched defeminizes herself. The institution isn't being painted here as a tool oppressive only to men, it is robbing everyone of their humanity.

I was really legitimately surprised by how much I enjoyed this novel. I was expecting something more sterile, more academic, I think. Really, this novel is a wonderfully emotional book, while diagnosing the modern schizophrenic disconnect of the individual from the mechanical institutions of society by a demonization of the natural impulse (even laughter is foreign to the men of the ward). It mirrors in some ways a lot of the reading I've been doing lately (Catch-22, Rousseau, Marx) in highlighting the dangers of modernity: in this case, that, in the face of an insane institution, the sane man is necessarily a lunatic.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
My literary hat is off to Ken Kesey for writing one of the best English language novels of the 20th century! It belongs on the shelf next to [[ASIN:0156030306 Flowers for Algernon]], [[ASIN:0316769487 The Catcher in the Rye]], [[ASIN:0679745653 Breakfast at Tiffany's and Three Stories]], [[ASIN:0743273567 The Great Gatsby]], and other great American novels that took characters to new heights in the past century. The title of novel is taken from a children's rhyme:

Vintery, mintery, cutery, corn,
Apple seed and apple thorn,
Wire, briar, limber lock
Three geese in a flock
One flew East
One flew West
And one flew over the cuckoo's nest

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest shines brilliance in every corner of the dark asylum in which it's based. It's a place where patients are hosed down, tied to their beds at night, their mouths stuffed with colorful pills to make them behave and if they don't, if they should dare challenge the bulking nurse--Miss Ratched--they are given a ticket to the amusement park funland called the electro-shock therapy lab.

The novel is told from the POV of an American Indian who has no business being in an insane asylum other than to escape his oppressive upbringing. Times are hard until McMurphy enters the asylum. The Jack Nicholson movie of the same name is quite good, too, but even the great actor cannot measure up to McMurphy, the character he plays in the movie. He lands in the looney bin for no other reason than to escape a hard labor sentence for his crimes. That's when the fun really begins as he incites the others to stand up for themselves against the oppressive regime.

One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest was published in 1962, nearly 120 years after Charles Dickens toured the North East insane asylums of America, which he recounted in his \\"American Notes.\\" There he told of a cruel system that did little to rehabilitate the insane. Edgar Allan Poe and many others felt Boz did American wrong when he returned to England and wrote his unflattering account. Three years later Edgar Allan Poe would pen one of the first English language short stories set in an insane asylum (\\"The System of Doctor Tarr and Professor Fether\\"), in which he lampooned many politicians of the day as analyzed in [[ASIN:1933747188 Edgar Allan Poe's Annotated Short Stories]].

Sadly, little had changed from the Victorian Age of Dickens and Poe, to the early 1960s when Kesey published OFOCN. The novel, however, did what Charles Dickens was unable to do by changing the way the insane were treated in America. It's still not a perfect system and probably never will be, but one that is less reliant on drugs and that has nearly eliminated lobotomies. So says my aunt who spent nearly her entire career as a nurse in an insane asylum. I can still remember as a boy, sitting wide-eyed around the table, while she told of the many fascinating things that when on there. Some of them were funny and some were downright creepy. I thought it would be impossible to attempt to capture these fascinating characters into a novel. Heck, I thought it crazy to even try.

Yet, Kesey has somehow accomplished it. He has distilled the experience (based on his own time spent working at an asylum) into one fantastic novel where freedom triumphs over oppression and conformance, when it is coherent and not drugged up or sent smoldering to bed after a few hundred volts were applied to the temples.did American wrong when he returned to England and wrote his unflattering account. Three years later Edgar Allan Poe would pen one of the first English language short stories set in an insane asylum (\\"The System of Doctor Tarr and Professor Fether\\"), in which he lampooned many politicians of the day as analyzed in [[ASIN:1933747188 Edgar Allan Poe's Annotated Short Stories]].

Sadly, little had changed from the Victorian Age of Dickens and Poe, to the early 1960s when Kesey published OFOCN. The novel, however, did what Charles Dickens was unable to do by changing the way the insane were treated in America. It's still not a perfect system and probably never will be, but one that is less reliant on drugs and that has nearly eliminated lobotomies. So says my aunt who spent nearly her entire career as a nurse in an insane asylum. I can still remember as a boy, sitting wide-eyed around the table, while she told of the many fascinating things that when on there. Some of them were funny and some were downright creepy. I thought it would be impossible to attempt to capture these fascinating characters into a novel. Heck, I thought it crazy to even try.

Yet, Kesey has somehow accomplished it. He has distilled the experience (based on his own time spent working at an asylum) into one fantastic novel where freedom triumphs over oppression and conformance, when it is coherent and not drugged up or sent smoldering to bed after a few hundred volts were applied to the temples.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I did not like the novel One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest because it was not the type of book I would normally read. It was vague and pointless in my opinion. I recommend it to anyone who likes books that are similar to that one.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: The world needs more Ken Kesey. ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOOS NEST unravels in such an earnest and free way. I do not want to spoil this story for the reader. Within lies one of the greatest works of human empathy, towards those who get none, ever written. A modern tale that ranges from commentary on the mental health institution, the definition of education, and how we judge sanity. The story is told from the point of view of an Indian, and ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOOS NEST gives weight to many of its messages through this character's viewpoint. A classic work.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: This is an amazing book.  I just finished it about 15 minutes ago and my head is still spinning--like, I can't word my way into a proper review, I can only wave my arms and jump up and down.  It is a RIDICULOUSLY good read.  I have read a lot of fiction, psychology, philosophy, and religion in my day, and this takes the cake as probably the greatest piece of writing (fiction-wise, if not of all of literature) that I have ever had the privilege of reading.  It is a masterpiece.  Do you hear me?  *shakes fist in the air* A MASTERPIECE!  I enthusiastically recommend this book to anyone and everyone for any and every reason.  It is that good.  Like damn.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: No More Rabbits: Chief Bromden, the Individual and Society
review_body:
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest was the last book I read before the end of the year, and it definitely makes my \\"Best Of\\" list. I have seen the film several times, but the book differs in a very key way. The narrator of the book is the presumably deaf/mute Chief Bromden, and his running commentary gives the book a different flavor from the film. His status as being supposedly deaf and mute gives him access to the asylum's dirtiest secrets, and it is fascinating to see the action through his eyes. \\"I had to keep on acting deaf if I wanted to hear at all,\\" he states.

It is interesting to look at Chief Bromden as a possible unreliable narrator in the novel. We know from page one that he is in a mental hospital, and the Chief has had several rounds of treatment in the \\"shock shop.\\" He even has episodes where he returns to his youth in his mind, filling out his fascinating backstory. Bromden played high school football and is partially driven mad when his father, the first \\"Chief Bromden\\" in the book, is swindled out of his tribe's land on the Columbia River, where they have speared and net fished the salmon going upstream at Celilo Falls for generations. Ultimately the Dalles Dam is built, covering the entire area with water in 1957. Celilo Falls is an interesting bit of history in itself, and it makes for fascinating reading.

Bromden tries to give a factual account of what is going on inside the hospital to the best of his ability, but that account is somewhat slanted because we see it only through the lens of his illness. He is paranoid to the point of thinking that there is a \\"Combine\\" that manipulates and controls individuals in subtle ways, such as machinery in the floors and walls. His paranoia is exacerbated by Nurse Ratched's very real iron hand in the running of things on her ward. In a critique of the novel, author Richard Gray explains that Bromden's vision \\"may not be literally true but it is symbolically so because, to quote Emily Dickinson... `Much madness is divinest sense.'\\" Traditionally an unreliable narrator is a narrator whose credibility has been severely compromised, usually to deceive the reader. Although Chief Bromden is clearly delusional from his schizophrenia (oozing walls, buried machinery, shrinking and growing people), he is at least trying to tell the truth as he sees it, for the greater good of the other patients.

Bromden reveals his ability to hear and speak to McMurphy, a free spirit who cons his way into the hospital faking insanity, thinking that time spent there will be easier than the jail sentence he is serving. McMurphy immediately locks horns with Nurse Ratched and bucks the system in a classic clash of the individual against the establishment. Chief Bromden and the other patients take heart at McMurphy's antics, and finally begin to come into their own as people instead of being scared and manipulated by Nurse Ratched, who only seems comfortable when wielding ultimate control over them. After a wild after-hours party on the ward near the end of the novel, one of the patients named Harding says that he is nearly ready to leave on his own, with all \\"the traditional red tape,\\" and that the others are \\"still sick men in lots of ways. But at least there's that: they are sick men now. No more rabbits, Mack.\\"

Author Ken Kesey's inspiration for the book came from the time he spent working as an orderly on the night shift at the Menlo Park Veteran's Hospital, a mental health facility in California. He saw how the institution worked and interviewed patients. During his time there he also volunteered for Project MKUltra, a covert research operation by the CIA's Scientific Intelligence division experimenting in the \\"behavioral engineering of humans,\\" which included experimentation on subjects with psychoactive drugs such as Peyote and LSD. Kesey's experimentation and writings eventually went on to influence the counter cultural movement in the United States and elsewhere in the mid to late 1960's.

One Flew over the Cuckoo's nest is a great and entertaining read with timeless themes that give you a lot to think about long after finishing the last page. Author Ken Kesey's portrayal of the struggle of the individual against authority holds as much power in today's deeply divided social and political climate as it did upon publication in 1962. Very highly recommended.es and elsewhere in the mid to late 1960's.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I got it for my girlfriend and she seems quite satisfied with it. The condition was great. Two thumbs up.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: A grand story rich with action, drama, and humor!
review_body:
Ken Kesey creates a grand story using literary skills, a good sense of dialogue, and unbeatable characters. The story is told behind the observant and quiet eyes of Chief Bromden, who springs the words to life as if the reader were listening to him speaking around a campfire. The Chief tells of his experiences in a mental institution ruled by the guileful Big Nurse who is challenged by the boisterous and charming newcomer, Randle P. McMurphy. McMurphy fills the ward with life, adventure, and defiance towards meager rules, going against the status quo of not only the Big Nurse, but also the shrouded controllers and manipulators of the world. The battle is packed with ups and downs and many surprises which lead to a realistic and inspiring ending. Though, the novel isn't a complete roller coaster of excitement. In fact, whenever McMurphy isn't in the scene, the pace of the book tends to slow down. The narrator, Chief Bromden, often delves into the description of major themes such as shrouded tyranny, fear, insecurity, and the importance of individuality with great detail and many literary devises. This leads the reader to think over many things while also enjoying the action and comedy throughout the novel.
Reading intensely through the novel, I appreciated every aspect it had to offer. The enjoyment of reading and ability to connect it to my life has further inspired me and I hope one day to match the story's natural goodness with experiences to come.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
This is really one of my favorite books of all time.
It is true that the book is ~always~ better than the movie!

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest; A great read
review_body: Everyone longs to be free and accepted for who they are.  One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest by Ken Kesey is an extraordinary novel that portrays this wonderfully. It all starts with a mental asylum; Chief, the narrator of the story, tells us about the atrocious nurse and the melancholy patients. Everyone just sits around all day, and follows the same schedule day by day until Randle McMurphy shows up. He would be considered the protagonist of the story. He doesn't have the same beliefs as the malicious, ancient nurse Ratched. He tries everything in his power, all day and every day to change her revolting rules. He does succeed some but you can only accomplish so much. She is the head of the asylum and he is just a measly patient.  Who do you think would win? There are many themes in this novel. One of the main themes is freedom. It is what some of the patients long for and what others don't think they deserve. You will see the theme of freedom in this novel often.  Another core theme would be rebellion. Rebellion is McMurphy's middle name, but in this novel that isn't bad. He is just trying to get everyone to be actual people again by showing them how to be normal. For example, he wants them to laugh, watch the World Series and play cards. Also, the ending was not my favorite, but I do believe it was an outstanding ending that shows us what our world has come to and what society can do to you. Other than that, I truly liked this book. You laughed sometimes, and wanted to cry sometimes, and occasionally you would want to yell at the nurse. Ken Kesey did a great job tugging at your emotions. I believe everyone should read this book. I believe this because it shows you how blessed you are to be free and it tells you to always be yourself; to stand you for what you believe in. Any book by Ken Kesey would be a winner. Furthermore, this book needs to be read and heard.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: This book was quite an interesting read. It kept me interested from start to finish. I heard the movie was excellent, but I wanted to read the book first.
