product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Whilst reading this book as part of a psychology report for school as well as an interested fan of the movie (which is nothing like the book) i loved every page and quirky detail!!

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest was a novel following the life of a prisoner McMurphy who got himself moved from a working prison to a mental hospital in the 1960's.  It follows the up's and downs of his journey and growing relationships with other patients in the mental ward run by the ultimate villain Nurse Ratchet or 'The Big Nurse' who enjoys using her power in her role as caregiver to employ other sadistic caregivers and to inflict pain and mental, and physical anguish on the patients who are left in her care.  I decided to read this book because I have loved the movie since my early teens, and although the characters were colorful, and the plot was one that you did not want to put down, I did find the writing style confusing and somewhat monotonous throughout the second half and towards the end of the book.  I do think however if you are interested into a look into what psychological treatment might have been like for patients during this point in history (1960's) this might be a good reference to read, or I'd recommend the movie.  As far as the novel itself its not one of my favorites but it was alright.  For me as someone with multiple psychology degrees hearing how the author chose to have the patients describe themselves, and their disorders was very interesting, and hearing how their main caregiver used therapy to manipulate them for her own means to really in a way torture then psychologically was disturbing to me and just makes me want to help people in a positive way even more.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
This book is still relevant today. Kesey provides a brilliant critique of American society.
However, the movie that was made from the book is quite bland.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I can't believe I never read this book. Fantastic, a real must read. Of course the movie's not bad either!

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: One Flew over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I give a rating for this novel an 8/10 because I felt the way the theme was portrayed was in a very meaningful manner e.g. how the characters said about how they felt. However I wished that more events happened because I found myself yawning and bored at times while reading. I would recommend this novel to others because I was very satisfied overall with the book.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: This book is brilliant. In less than the words required. Great story, beautiful writing. Read this book soon and enjoy.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
Don't know where to begin. I want to be able to articulate this brilliant book in big fancy words, but I can't. It's beyond my vocabulary. It's about the man against the system, and its written so eloquently, but the eloquence hides underneath the rough, the primitive, the every day stuff that doesn't hold much sophistication. And yet, it's poetry. At times entire passages in this book made me want to reread them again and again, they were so beautiful. Have you ever read a book that seemed to send a very important message and yet when you tried articulating it to someone, no sound came out, and all you could do is just feel? Feel this cocktail of emotions you couldn't explain? That's how I feel. The story itself is simple. Some guy gets committed into an asylum and tries to fight some nurse who has established a firm grip on her ward and isn't going to suddenly change things because of one stranger. It would be too simple to describe it like this. There are so many layers here, and yet all of them are portrayed so straightforward, they left me speechless. I think more than anything this book is about the poison of unhappiness and how it can infect everything around it, crushing life to death. The poison is the nurse, and one who tried to challenge her is Randle McMurphy. But I'm getting ahead of myself. Let me tell you what the story is about.

The story is told by Chief "Bromden", a large man whom everyone thinks deaf and mute, whiling away his time as a committed patient in the nuthouse. Enter Randle McMurphy who pretends to be crazy to escape prison and lands himself in the same asylum. He is initially shocked at the atmosphere on the ward, the surgical cleanliness, the order, the lack of humanity in patients, who are afraid to even laugh out loud, all fisted in the firm grip of the head nurse. Randle takes it upon himself to challenge the order and bring life into the inhabitants, locking horns with the nurse, Ms. Ratched, except it's not her who is the enemy, it's the entire system of institutionalization. They engage in power struggle that gradually escalates to a heart breaking end. Along the lines, Randle manages to change the lives of those who have spent years and years thinking they couldn't toe the line chalked across the floor for them, except it comes at a price. I would say, this book accomplishes an astounding study into human psyche pigeonholed into a mechanical existence, processed and sorted and distributed like a thing, and various ways of escaping this oppression. There are, really, only a few, either to physically make a run for it, or to escape into madness, or, the most extreme solution, death, either by suicide or by succumbing to be crushed. I will be rereading this book, to pick up more layers, because I feel like I only scratched the surface and there is more, more to learn and to marvel at and to comprehend. Ken Kesey is a genius.who is the enemy, it's the entire system of institutionalization. They engage in power struggle that gradually escalates to a heart breaking end. Along the lines, Randle manages to change the lives of those who have spent years and years thinking they couldn't toe the line chalked across the floor for them, except it comes at a price. I would say, this book accomplishes an astounding study into human psyche pigeonholed into a mechanical existence, processed and sorted and distributed like a thing, and various ways of escaping this oppression. There are, really, only a few, either to physically make a run for it, or to escape into madness, or, the most extreme solution, death, either by suicide or by succumbing to be crushed. I will be rereading this book, to pick up more layers, because I feel like I only scratched the surface and there is more, more to learn and to marvel at and to comprehend. Ken Kesey is a genius.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Funny, heartbreaking, and inspiring.  Although a great movie on it's own merit, the book far surpasses the film. Isn't that always the way?

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Great character development!! Author weaved a fantastic tale of truth, sadness, and humor! A big must read for anr book club.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: As of today, the kindle version has no mistakes and is formatted correctly; ignore low stars reviews of the kindle edition written in previous years as they are no longer relevant.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: When i first opened the book the day it was assigned to me in the 10th grade and began to read the words on the pages the first thought that came to my mind is wtf was my teacher making me read.  This Chief character makes no sense with his speak of fog and people growing in size and such.  But as we began to discuss it in class, and as Chief's thoughts began to grow clearer i fell in love with the book.  In my opinion, if you cant comprehend difficult subjects on your own, and you dont have a teacher or someone to explain this book, dont read it.  But if you enjoy books about complete nuts and dont mind having to work for the meaning behind the words, i say that this will be one of the best novels you have ever read

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: This book is a classic for a reason.  Amazing writing.  (Much better than the movie btw.)  Still relevant to the mental health care industry today. Read this novel.  You wonâ€™t be disappointed.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I picked this book up because I was intrigued with Ken Kesey after watching a documentary on him, and now that intrigue has only been replaced with fascination! What an incredible book.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Eh it was alright it wasn't great but it was eh. Never wanna read this book again in my life

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
I love great characters. One Flew made me want to write a novel on an aging minister who was losing his mind after the death of his wife. My novel is [[ASIN:B0086VUQM2 Going Nuts ebook]]
I love a story where the craziest are the most relevant.
David W. Jones

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
I had heard a lot about this book, and was not disappointed. Expert crafting of a story, with a scarily good peak into the human psyche and the overall intentions of the 'psychology' industry. Sadly, this book is still very relevant today, with big pharmaceutical companies forcing happy pills down everyone's throats and sociopathic psychiatrists writing dangerous prescriptions willy nilly to make a quick buck. I'll get off my soap box now...

Definitely one of those books I would consider a must read. A book that grips you and tears at your heart strings, so to speak, and leaves you with a new outlook on things. If you like to read books that have meaning, pick this up.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
This boos is a piece of classic literature, it is extraordinary in multiple levels: both the storyline and the allegory.
It does have its drawbacks where the storyteller goes into reflective mode and sometimes the diversions are just too long (for me at least). Nevertheless, as a whole the book is absorbing.

Additionally, it definitely scores high in my subjective measuring of the quality of a book by the discussion it triggers with another person (both quality and length)

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Seen the movie several times, somehow didn't realize the story is told from the Indians perspective.  Great transitions between reality and crazy, and the Big Nurse is as loathsome on paper as on the big screen.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: love this author and love this book. also recommend watching the movie with Jack Nicholson. it is an old one but it is true to the book and very good.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Sadly, I am not even able to finish this novel. I think this is the closest I have ever come to not being able to understand the English language. I honestly believe that Kesey must have been using a lot of LSD as he wrote this book. The passages are very long-winded and there are no freakin' chapter breaks. Ulimately it all comes down to a matter of style--that which does not agree with my personal reading taste. I'm certain I would have finished this book if I had read it many years ago, but not now with the digital age giving us instant access to millions of books. It's easier to just move on. Life is too short to read books that don't sit well with your mental stomach.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I loved the ending. Makes you wonder what WOULD happen if a sane person were confined to such an institution, would they remain sane? Or if the institution really does help vs. further institutionalize the person.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: Edge of your seat type of read!
review_body: 5 Stars for the amazing tale of bravery, deceit, and the fighting glory of Randle McMurphy. The ending got me a bit upset and messed with my emotions but that's what makes this book so amazing.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I had heard good things about this book but it didn't live up to the hype. Perhaps I'm missing the symbolism but it isn't as touching or thought provoking as I anticipated.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: Misrepresented Item -Wish I Could Get Refund
review_body: This is NOT the novel, but that fact is not expressed in the item description. This is an adapted play. Don't be fooled. Dishonest descriptions should not be allowed.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: fascinating novel about the inner workings of a mental institution
review_body: I enjoyed the characters in this book very much. The story draws you in and has you rooting for McMurphy and the other inmates. Highly recommend.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: Disturbed and distorted, a classic yet
review_body: Disturbed and distorted this book is, it offers a great insight into mental states and what comes out of introducing an outstanding character into a steady, repetitive world. No wonder why this book became such a classic. I was thrilled with the narrating choice, and the symbolism of the book conveyed through the character.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Unlike most of my reviews, I really don't have a lot to say about this one.  Most people have seen the awesome movie made from this book, starring Jack Nicholson, playing probably is most famous role, so I don't need to recount the details of the plot, which are nearly identical.  Where the movie shines, and where the book doesn't is in the characters.  The characters in the movie were much better than the book, they seemed stale and flat, even McMurphy and the Nurse in the book just didn't have half the impact that Jack Nicholson and Louise Fletcher hit you with in the movie.  In the end, what this book really needs is a serious editing, because many of the chapters just drone on and on long after the author has made his point.  He doesn't just beat the dead horse, he mangles it.  However, fans of the movie will still see many of the great scenes in this book (which, like I said, are nearly identical in parts), and that at least has some appreciation value.  I'm not sorry I read it, but the movie was just much better, and I can only truly say that about a handful of books.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: So well written. The characters were incredibly vividly portrayed. No wonder they made a movie out of it.Jack Nicholson was perfectly cast as the lead in the movie I read this book long ago, but it was quite an enjoyable reread.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: The evolution of the characters in this book is so intriguing. It's an easy but interesting read, I really loved it.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Such a wonderful book. I loved the character development throughout, and you really fall in love with each character, aside from the nurse. It made me laugh. It made me think. It made me cry. I would recommend this book to anyone looking for a easy and interesting read.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest tells the tale of Randall McMurphy attempting to disrupt the power structure controlling both him and the other patients of an insane asylum.
A powerful fable of man's struggle for freedom.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body:
Big Nurse rules with an iron hand and a jaundiced eye. She's the power behind The Combine. She walks the mental ward,stiff, with rubber heels clicking. She nods once to each patient resident. A precise, automatic gesture. Her face is smooth, calculated, precision made like an expensive baby doll. One with fangs.
Chief Bromden, the seemingly mute half-Indian, observes, witnesses, understands McMurphy's heroic attempt to slam-up against her awesome, unlimited power.
\\"My name is McMurphy, buddies, R.P.McMurphy, and I'm a gambling fool.\\" He stands, looking at us, rocking in his boots, and he laughs and laughs. \\"No body left in that Pendleton Work Farm, so I requested a transfer, ya see. Needed some new blood.\\" The way he talks, his wink, his swagger all remind me of a car salesman, or a stock auctioneer--or one of those pitchmen you see on a sideshow stage. Men when you lose your laugh you lose your footing.
Just as she's rolling along at her biggest and meanest, McMurphy steps out of the latrine door right in front of her, holding that towel around his hips. \\"Towels against ward policy, too? Well, I guess there's nothing to do exce...\\"
\\"Now, lobotomy, that's chopping away part of the brain?\\" \\"You're becoming very sophisticated in the jargon. Yes, chopping away the brain. Frontal-lobe castration. If she can't cut below the belt she'll do it above the eyes.\\"
He discovered many things. Most of the vulnerable men had not been committed, they were volunteers, yet they stayed, bitching, griping, conforming to policy.
McMurphy could not walk that walk, nor, talk that talk. He worried over a new thought like a dog worries at a new hole. After a deliberate cigarette ploy, he ran his hand through her Nurse's Station glass. McMurphy said, \\"That window glass was so slick and span I com-pletely forgot it was there.\\"
This is boisterous, preposterous, ribald, sadly comic, and an ultimately shattering glimpse into the men's wards of a mental institution. The conflict power struggle that arises between a steel-fisted charge nurse, and a more than lucidly competent resident. I laughed. I wanted to cry, but didn't, because tears blur the vision. Excellent!

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I didn't know what to expect when I bought this book. I am very happy that I decided to get it. It kept me intrigued and is written in a way I've never read.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Great story with lots of wonderful characters and deep emotional meaning. I will read this many more times--and cry a lot.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Ken Kessey uses the written word to bring us into a world where the lines between ill and well, between mad and brilliant, between evil and necessary, and between human and non-human are blurred while leaving us with the realization that this world is, in fact, our world.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I was expecting a little more from this book. I found it hard to follow at times but overall I did like it. In my opinion, the movie is much better.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I love this book and was shocked anyone would give this book a 1 star, but when you see their other reviews it snaps into focus. The have horrible taste.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: One of the best books I have managed to read in a while.
review_body: It a great book and I encourage others to read this book it's sad it funny beautiful and it will keep you reading

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Great book. If you've only seen the movie, read it. Many little (and one big) detail make it much more engrossing. The book was written from Chief's point of view, which makes makes much more sense of it all, especially if you consider the ending. Totally recommend.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest review
review_body: I liked this book because it was just the right amount of challenging. At parts i disliked it, though, because it was a bit confusing with all of the narrative switches. I would recommend this book for very advanced readers who read books that are in a reading level higher than the average person of their age reads.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: Such a sad book! Great read, though, I highly recommend it to anyone looking for something they can call a classic.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I just finished this book a few minutes ago and have to say that I really enjoyed it. I would recommend this book to my friends and family.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: My review is for the price point.  I am currently at a major bookstore and the paperback book is the same price as what amazon is offering it on kindle.  I have a membership to this bookstore so actually the book would be cheaper.  Its really disappointing that I am not getting a discount or a cheaper book by being \\"green\\" and not buying a paper product of a book that is 50 years old.  It is actually quite obnoxious.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I recently heard an NPR conversation about the 50th anniversary of \\"One Flew over the Cuckoo's nest\\"; the conversation referred to author Kesey's displeasure over the movie.  I decided to read the book for the first time and then see the movie, which I had seen years ago.  What a great read and what a great movie.  Like most book-to-movie productions, the movie lacked the depth and nuances of the book and there is a key perspective shift from the book to the movie that I won't describe (it is such a pleasure to discover the shift by reading and watching.) Differences notwithstanding, both the book and movie are classics and thoroughly enjoyable and disturbing, and the stories behind the production of both are fascinating as well.  A must read-and-see, so glad I am so glad I did it.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: TYPOS EVERYWHERE in an otherwise amazing book
review_body: I found this Kindle version to be unreadable due to very frequent typos. Amazon needs to pay someone a few to proofread this if they're going to charge thousands of people $15.00 for it. For example page 93 \\"I Ic\\" is written instead of \\"He\\". Page 96 \\"1\\" is written instead of \\"I\\". Page 102 \\"I low\\" is written instead of \\"How\\". Page 104 \\"1\\" for \\"I\\". Page 104 \\"I le's\\" for He's\\". That is a small sample of the typos throughout the whole book.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: This is a great book and I'm sure you can read the other reviews for insight into why it is so great, but the Kindle edition isn't very good.  It's like they ran the book through a cheap OCR and just threw it at Amazon.  There are lots of scanning errors.  'He' often comes thorough as 'I Ie' and the letter 'c' and 'e' appear to be interchangeable in multiple places.  Avoid the Kindle edition.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: First, this review is not a literary critique of the book.  It is a review of the digital download.    I'm a little over halfway through reading the book.  I'm not sure how the work was actually digitized, but the final product is full of editorial errors.  It looks similar to some of the documents that I've run through OCR in the past.  I would have expected that before the final product was sold online for $10.99 a copy, someone would have taken the trouble to proofread it.  I gave it a 3-star, \\"OK\\" rating because the volume is still readable even with the numerous errors.  However, it takes away from my overall satisfaction with the product when I have to stumble over these errors during my reading.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: I'm enjoying the novel, but have noticed quite a few typos, missing periods, etc. I don't know if it was just transferred to the electronic version sloppily, or if the print edition had the same errors.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_headline: Chuck Palahniuk DID NOT WRITE THIS
review_body:
This is a great book, one of my all time favorites. However, it is a little bothersome that when I look for it my Kindle its filed under Chuck Palahniuk, who is a fine author, but who also had NOTHING to do with this writing of this book.

Seriously, what the heck, you should fix that Amazon.

product_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
review_body: This novel was unlike anything I have ever read in the past. The narrator gives a different prospective from inside a 1960's mental institution.  Chief Boredman is a veteran at the Oregon clinic. He is the silent eyes and ears of the place. Everyone else believes that he is dumb, blind and deaf,yet he watches everything.  The ward is run by a very strict Nurse Ratched. Nobody defies her because of fear of electroshock therapy, which is looked down upon society yet still practiced in the ward. The whole dynamic of the ward changes when a gambling man named Randle McMurphy is admitted.  The first rebellion takes place when McMurphy rebels against the television schedule. After this, McMurphy encourages others to follow his lead and rebel against Nurse Ratched. The changes McMurphy makes to some paitents allow them freedom and impendence. In another case, McMurphy damages and drives one patient to a more insane state than before.  For the most part I really enjoyed this novel.  If I were to write this book I probably would have had a happier ending.  Positively thinking, it would have been a better ending if McMurphy and the patients rebelled against Nurse Ratched and won.  Also, if McMurphy didn't get drunk and fall asleep the whole plan to escape would have worked out a lot better. This is upsetting and I wish this would have worked out better in the end. I would recommend this book to people interested in psychology. A certain maturity age must also be required to enjoy this novel. This being, kids in high school will definitely appreciate One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. - s.rozycki
